children.value: The world compressed and left his face
Haloed like the moon
My bones they carried me away
To the only treasure I knew
This box all white and smooth
Inside the sweet scent of the East
I will offer you
These years of labor for a moment
Spilled at your feet
They railed at my weak condition
Wasteful and obscene
But love stole my inhibition
Left unstable tendencies
You're like a fire burning up this night
I don't know what came over me
Everything wanes in your warm light
All I have is at your feet
Long we have languished in midnight's monochrome
Dreaming of the brilliance that will bloom in these shadows
So we till the barrenness and scatter seeds of hope
Come, Lord Jesus in every hand we hold
Long we have journeyed o'er marshes, deserts, plains
Yearning for a causeway where children can be safe
So we tear down the injustice that keeps our peace in chains
Come, Lord Jesus in every step we take
Sacred light,Come and shine
Help us see, Your love grow brighter
With every selfless deed
Long we have listened to the tune of violence
Longing for the bright sounds of love to make amends
So we don the melody of love's generous strain
Come, Lord Jesus in every song we sing
Come, Lord Jesus in every warm embrace
Come, Lord Jesus in every stand we take
Come, Lord Jesus in every smile we bring
Come, Lord Jesus in every word we speak
Come, Lord Jesus
Come, Lord Jesus
If you’re hungry and feeling faint
Come to the riverside
Don't be shy now, fill your plate
Come to the riverside
Bring your burdens and lay them down
What you lack is no account
There is enough in God's good hands
Our broken pieces are blessed and shared
If you're tired and lost your way
Come to the riverside
Find a home in Love's embrace
Come to the riverside
Bring your worries and let them rest
No one here is perfect yet
As God uncovers life hidden deep
Our weakness loses its gravity
If you're sore and shuffling
Come to the riverside
These quiet waters will ease the sting
Come to the riverside
Bring your sorrows and set them free
Scatter them upon this breeze
Though some wounds will always ache
Peace may find you along the way

I didn't grow up observing Lent, but over the years I’ve come to appreciate this season more.  For brooding, artsy-fartsy types like me, it fits.  It’s nice to have a time of year when I can be “contemplative” rather than just plain moody.

I used to see Lent as constriction—a shoring up of our moralities and behavior.  But more and more, I see Lent as a widening.  It’s about exploring our interior landscapes, not navel-gazing.  It’s about making room, not austerity. It’s about release, not constriction.  It’s about reconnecting with the Source of life, not about disconnecting from all enjoyment.

I still have this tendency to think that God wants some proof of my allegiance—that somehow God is not satisfied with me as I am.  And so I can tend to turn Lent into another way that I have to prove myself to be worthy of Grace, to be worth saving.  But that is not the purpose of this season.  God is not looking for proof of our worthiness.  God is not keeping notes on if we prayed enough or if we used our “driving words” on the way home from work.

God is whispering to us, calling us out into the wide open spaces, leading us into fields of grace, pointing us to where the waving wheat of gratitude sways, inviting us to find the streams of fresh clear water that spring up in the most unexpected places.

Who knows what goodness may be born in our hearts when we make room for love to flower there, when we make room for life to grow and thrive? Who knows?  There may be less room for some things, but I don’t think we’ll miss them.

children.value: Jesus went to the desert to pray
Out in the heat for forty days
Didn't take money and didn't take food
Looking for God in the caves and the dunes
*Lord teach us to walk your way
Though we go through the shadow of death
Lord teach us to trust your time
Though your road is a steep, steep climb  *
Jesus went to the desert to hear
The whisper you can't catch with ears
Left the traffic and the industry
Listening for God with the rocks and the trees
Jesus went to the desert to see
The way of God in the waves of heat
Wiped his brow and closed his eyes
Lifted his hands up to the sky
Jesus went to the desert to pray
The devil came by to try his faith
He wouldn't take bribes and he wouldn’t give up
Climbing his way up the path of love
Though this road is long and winding
Though it weaves through shadows deep
Give us faith to work for justice
Even when we cannot see
Teach us lord to walk in mercy
Teach us lord to walk in truth
Teach us lord to walk in kindness
Teach us lord to walk with you
Though this road is steep and climbing
Though the way is treacherous
Give us hearts full of compassion
To raise our sisters and brothers up
We will follow through the nighttime
Cause you know our suffering
We will follow through the heartache
Till your love makes this world complete
Jesus put a towel around his waist
Jesus put a towel around his waist
Jesus donned a servant's garb
To expose the heart of God
Jesus put a towel around his waist
Jesus poured some water in a bowl
Jesus poured some water in a bowl
Jesus set the water free
To slake the thirst of homesick feet
Jesus poured some water in a bowl
Jesus got down on the dusty floor
Jesus got down on the dusty floor
Had no taste for power’s fare
Love was all his sustenance
Jesus got down on the dusty floor
Jesus washed the feet of his enemy
Jesus washed the feet of his enemy
Jesus touched the wayward soles
Thought far beyond the reach of God
Jesus washed the feet of his enemy
Jesus said now you go do the same
Jesus said now you go do the same
Get your bucket and get your towel
Love ain't interested in crowns
Jesus said now you go do the same
Come on in out the cold
Set down your bags take off your coat
There's room at the table for you
Come on over have a seat
It's a weary road rest your feet
There's room at the table for you
Lift a glass to thank our host
He carved these legs he planed this top
He pressed this wine with all his heart
And welcomes us just as we are
There's room at the table for you
Don't need a tie or fancy dress
You're fine like you are we're all friends
There's room at the table for you
Don't need rich kin or big degrees
The last are first, the least our most esteemed
There's room at the table for you
Pass the bread beans and corn
Don't be shy there's plenty more
There's room at the table for you
Pass the goodness pass the peace
Everybody's welcome to this feast
There's room at the table for you
Jesus went to the desert to pray
Out in the heat for forty days
Didn't take money and didn't take food
Looking for God in the caves and the dunes
*Lord teach us to walk your way
Though we go through the shadow of death
Lord teach us to trust your time
Though your road is a steep, steep climb  *

Lifted his hands up to the sky
Jesus went to the desert to pray
The devil came by to try his faith
He wouldn't take bribes and he wouldn’t give up
Climbing his way up the path of love

children.value: I like to make things.  Songs, stories, websites, logos, linocut prints, podcasts to name a few.  I've been a youth minister, worship leader, ESL instructor, front-end engineer, graphic designer and hot tub deliverer. I've always been drawn to corporate worship experiences, and I've been trying to find a language for worship that has legs to travel out of sanctuaries and into streets, bars, homes, and grocery stores.

From contemplations on scripture to liturgical themes and issues of social justice, songs and stories help me to make sense of what often feels senseless. Sometimes they just quietly honor the inherent beauty of trees or roads.
Some songs were written for singing together with friends.  Others may be better for whispering in the quiet.  Either way, I hope these contemplations help you on your journey.
If you want to use a song or story in a worship setting, feel free.  Attribution is always appreciated.
Listen, download, stream, support

You can catch these tunes on any number of streaming services or purchase and download at several retailers.  If you bootleg the songs and give them to a friend, thanks.  If you want to support the cause, you can become a sustaining member on Patreon and help fund the tune machine.

I like to make things.  Songs, stories, websites, logos, linocut prints, podcasts to name a few.  I've been a youth minister, worship leader, ESL instructor, front-end engineer, graphic designer and hot tub deliverer. I've always been drawn to corporate worship experiences, and I've been trying to find a language for worship that has legs to travel out of sanctuaries and into streets, bars, homes, and grocery stores.

From contemplations on scripture to liturgical themes and issues of social justice, songs and stories help me to make sense of what often feels senseless. Sometimes they just quietly honor the inherent beauty of trees or roads.
Some songs were written for singing together with friends.  Others may be better for whispering in the quiet.  Either way, I hope these contemplations help you on your journey.
If you want to use a song or story in a worship setting, feel free.  Attribution is always appreciated.
Listen, download, stream, support

You can catch these tunes on any number of streaming services or purchase and download at several retailers.  If you bootleg the songs and give them to a friend, thanks.  If you want to support the cause, you can become a sustaining member on Patreon and help fund the tune machine.

keys.value:
I like to make things. Songs, stories, websites, logos, linocut prints, podcasts to name a few. I've been a youth minister, worship leader, ESL instructor, front-end engineer, graphic designer and hot tub deliverer. I've always been drawn to corporate worship experiences, and I've been trying to find a language for worship that has legs to travel out of sanctuaries and into streets, bars, homes, and grocery stores.

From contemplations on scripture to liturgical themes and issues of social justice, songs and stories help me to make sense of what often feels senseless. Sometimes they just quietly honor the inherent beauty of trees or roads.

Some songs were written for singing together with friends. Others may be better for whispering in the quiet. Either way, I hope these contemplations help you on your journey.

If you want to use a song or story in a worship setting, feel free. Attribution is always appreciated.

Listen, download, stream, support

You can catch these tunes on any number of streaming services or purchase and download at several retailers. If you bootleg the songs and give them to a friend, thanks. If you want to support the cause, you can become a sustaining member on Patreon and help fund the tune machine.

children.value: Music and musings for seasons of life and liturgy to accompany you on your journey or encourage your faith community
Song quilting.
Word knitting.
Image weaving.
Somewhere deep inside
the truth of love exists.
A transcendental union
'tween the boundless
and the fixed.
